item.title: [Dementhium 639]It wont set or get because java sucks
item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

I am trying to make all this into a gambling game. I am just using godswords as a test.

Using these arrays

This

public String randomGodsword() { return Godswords[(int)(Math.random()*Godswords.length)]; }

These set and gets

public void setBet(String Godswords) { this.Godswords = Godswords; } public String getBet() { return Godswords; }

My compiler says they are incompatable. Why does java have to do this to me?
Here is an example of what I’m wanting it to do. It’s short to test it.

case 3001: sendDialogue(player, HAPPY_TALKING, 3001, 19951, "I want to bet my " + player.randomGodsword() + "."); player.setBet(player.randomGodsword()); return true;

case 19951: if (player.getBet().equalsIgnoreCase("Armadyl Godsword")) { sendDialogue(player, HAPPY_TALKING, 3001, -1, "No! Not my Armadyl Godsword."); player.getInventory().addItem(11694, 1); } else if (player.getBet().equalsIgnoreCase("Saradomin Godsword")) { sendDialogue(player, HAPPY_TALKING, 3001, -1, "No! Not my Saradomin Godsword."); player.getInventory().addItem(11698, 1); } else if (player.getBet().equalsIgnoreCase("Zamorak Godsword")) { sendDialogue(player, HAPPY_TALKING, 3001, -1, "No! Not my Zamorak Godsword."); player.getInventory().addItem(11700, 1); } else if (player.getBet().equalsIgnoreCase("Bandos Godsword")) { sendDialogue(player, HAPPY_TALKING, 3001, -1, "No! Not my Bandos Godsword"); player.getInventory().addItem(11696, 1); } return true;

I want it so that if he bets a godsword named “Something Godsword” randomly out of 4 it will give the one he bet to me.

Why can’t it just be made so we can make arrays be returned…
Can someone tell me how I can write this differently

Read full topic
item.source: [Dementhium 639]It wont set or get because java sucks
